references.A51ALC01USGP: Alcorn, J.R., and F. Richardson. 1951. The Chukar Partridge in Nevada. Journal of Wildlife Management, 15:265-275.
references.A02WAL01USGP: Walter, H. 2002. Natural history and ecology of the chukar (Alectoris chukar) in the northern Great Basin. Great Basin Birds 5(1):28-37.
references.W96CHR01USGP: Christensen, Glen C. 1996. Chukar (Alectoris chukar), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/258
references.B90ZEI03NAUS: Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.
references.O94SUL01USGP: Sullivan, Janet. 1994. Alectoris chukar. In: Fire Effects Information System, [Online]. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory (Producer). Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/ [2012, September 27].
references.O03LEE01USGP: Lee, R., E. Perkins, and J. Staley. 2003. Strategic management plan for chukar partridge (Alectoris chukar). Utah Division of Wildlife Resources, Upland Game Advisory Committee.
references.A07LAR01USGP: Larsen, R.T., J.T. Flinders, D.L. Mitchell, E.R. Perkins, and D.G. Whiting. 2007. Chukar watering patterns and water site selection. Rangeland Ecology and Management, 60(6):559-565.
references.B91DEG01USGP:
DeGraaf, R.M., V.E. Scott, R.H. Hamre, L.Ernst and S.H Anderson. 1991. Forest and Rangeland birds

references.R76MOL01USGP: Molini, W. A. 1976. Chukar Partridge species management plan. Nev. Dept. Fish and Game, Reno.

habitat_description:
Alectoris chukar primarily inhabits sagebrush-grasslands (Christensen, 1970; Zeiner et al., 1990; Sullivan, 1994; Lee et al., 2003; Larsen et al., 2007) as well as saltbush-grass and other short shrub-steppe environments (Christensen, 1970; Sullivan, 1994; Lee et al., 2003), sometimes with scattered pinyon-juniper (Alcorn and Richardson, 1951; Christensen, 1970; Sullivan, 1994; Lee et al., 2003; Larsen et al., 2007), and typically with a grass-forb understory (Christensen, 1970).  The species requires at least 10% shrub cover to reduce predation risk (Larsen et al., 2007). Chukar will also use talus, scree, and other steep, rocky slopes for cover and as escape terrain (Alcorn and Richardson, 1951; Zeiner et al., 1990; Walter, 2002; Lee et al., 2003). Eight days after a fire, 2,000 chukars were documented within burned shrub/grassland (Christensen, 1970).

In summer, the species remains near water sources (Alcorn and Richardson, 1951; Lee et al., 2003)

It avoids dense pinyon-juniper (Christensen, 1970; Lee et al., 2003).

Chukars have been known to feed on singleleaf pinon, rabbitbrush, lupine, Poa spp., cottonwood, wheat, and corn (Alcorn and Richardson, 1951).

Elevations at which the species has been sighted range from below sea level in California to 3659 m in the White Mountains of California and Nevada (Christensen, 1996).
